trans-unit.source: To better illustrate how to create UDRs, this document will use the scenario below.
trans-unit.target: To better illustrate how to create UDRs, this document will use the scenario below.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario you will create one UDR for the *Front end subnet* and another UDR for the *Back end subnet* , as described below:
trans-unit.target: In this scenario you will create one UDR for the *Front end subnet* and another UDR for the *Back end subnet* , as described below:

trans-unit.source: The front end UDR will be applied to the *FrontEnd* subnet, and contain one route:
trans-unit.target: The front end UDR will be applied to the *FrontEnd* subnet, and contain one route:

trans-unit.source: This route will send all traffic to the back end subnet to the **FW1** virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This route will send all traffic to the back end subnet to the **FW1** virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The back end UDR will be applied to the *BackEnd* subnet, and contain one route:
trans-unit.target: The back end UDR will be applied to the *BackEnd* subnet, and contain one route:

trans-unit.source: This route will send all traffic to the front end subnet to the **FW1** virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This route will send all traffic to the front end subnet to the **FW1** virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The combination of these routes will ensure that all traffic destined from one subnet to another will be routed to the **FW1** virtual machine, which is being used as a virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: The combination of these routes will ensure that all traffic destined from one subnet to another will be routed to the **FW1** virtual machine, which is being used as a virtual appliance.

trans-unit.source: You also need to turn on IP forwarding for that VM, to ensure it can receive traffic destined to other VMs.
trans-unit.target: You also need to turn on IP forwarding for that VM, to ensure it can receive traffic destined to other VMs.
